title: Basics of Maritime Logistics
headline: This free online course explains how to navigate various logistic and legal concerns facing ships at sea.
description: This free online course teaches you the differences between intermodal and multimodal transportation and lays out the fundamentals of shipping markets. We break down the role of the International Commercial Terms and delve into supply chains and the principles that guide their management. Sign up to learn how maritime freight still keeps the world supplied with goods from many shores.
courseDescription:
This free online course introduces you to the world’s trade patterns and explains how they affect global trading as we break down the basic functions of multilateral trading systems. We lay out the preconditions and major drivers of trade. We then cover the differences between intermodal and multimodal transportation and the basics of shipping markets.

This course then identifies the different stakeholders in cargo movement and the roles of various cargo interests. We outline the risks involved in the export of goods and the impact of the International Commercial Terms (INCOTERMS). We then take you through the integration of maritime transport and logistics and the different perspectives of supply chain management.

We then move on to planning in break bulk shipping transit and examine the economic regulation of liner shipping. This free online course suits anyone with an interest in maritime logistics and wants to understand the fundamentals of shipping markets.

Start Course Now

slides:
• Learning Outcomes 
  • Upon the successful completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Analyze world trade patterns and how they affect global trading. 
    • Identify the basic functions of the multilateral trading system. 
    • Discuss why tariffs, duties or import restrictions are imposed. 
    • Outline the preconditions for trading. 
    • Outline the major drivers of the trading industry. 
    • Explain the major trade blocs of the world. 
  • Global Trade Changes
  • Global trade continues to accelerate both in volumes and complexity, with the WTO’s most recent trade forecast revised to show improved growth in world merchandise trade volume. Just look at the numbers from Alibaba and their most recent Singles Day, where products were purchased from 192 countries. 

    The number of tons shipped by ocean containers has multiplied many times over in recent years-almost 17 times-from 102 million tons in 1980, to 1,720 million tons in 2016. After years of stagnation, trade has been soaring as an upturn across major global economies picking up momentum However, Political unrest, myriad of and ever-increasing regulatory requirements including veiled protectionism have all added to layers of distress.

  • The volume of world trade continued to grow slowly in 2015 recording growth of 2.7 per cent in April 2016. Trade growth was roughly in line with world GDP growth of 2.4 per cent. The current dollar value of world merchandise exports is at US$ 16.0 trillion.

  • Multilateral Trading System Under the WTO
  • The multilateral trading system under the WTO aims to encourage free and fair trade globally. The most basic goal is to eliminate tariffs on goods moving between countries. However, even if tariffs are eliminated, trade is not necessarily fully free if there are other, non-tariff barriers restricting trade.

    Countries have historically used many strategies to restrict imports in order to protect their local industries. The global trade system functions optimally when countries agree to import goods that they don’t produce competitively, but are free to export goods they do produce competitively.

    An example of a non-tariff barrier is complexity of paperwork involved in customs clearance and excessive administrative fees. Another may be a local health and safety regulation when there is no scientific basis. For example, consider that a shipment of apples enters country A. First, it has to clear Customs, which it does after verification that tariffs have been paid. The shipment can’t enter the country officially until the agricultural inspection service certifies that the goods are free of disease. 

    In most cases, these inspections are a legitimate way for Country A to protect its citizens. But if Country A is trying to protect its local apple growers, the inspectors might delay shipment and this could result in excessive warehouse fees at the port of arrival and perhaps the spoilage of the shipment. This is an example of a non-tariff barrier.

  • Imposition of Tariffs
  • The imposition of tariffs or duties is necessary to check the unfair exchange of goods between countries. A protection or retaliatory action such as temporary duty is imposed to resolve such problems.

    Prior to the imposition of income taxes, which is a relatively recent phenomenon, customs duties often provided the primary source of Government revenues. The second reason for the imposition of tariffs is to protect and nurture a home grown industry.

    India’s protection of the automobile industry is a classic example of the use of high tariffs to protect a home grown industry. Today, in a major Indian city like Mumbai, you will see many older model cars. This is because low priced and higher quality imports have not been allowed into the country. This protectionist policy has prevented the Indian auto industry from modernizing and thus it does not build internationally known vehicles.

    In contrast, US automakers were exposed to global competition and although US automakers have struggled in recent times, their products have continually improved to compete against foreign competition. The bottom line is that opening the local industry to foreign competition is a painful process that often results in severe dislocation and hardship, but ultimately results in a more competitive industry.

  • Preconditions of Trade
  • The most basic precondition for trade is peace. When nations are at war, they do not trade. As soon as World War II ended, one of the first initiatives was to create the GATT so as to restart the process of global trade, which had decimated during the war.

    Trade requires the presence of a stable government as a precondition for its ability to buy and sell goods in the international market. In order to trade effectively, a country has to have a functioning internal economy, which should include basic infrastructure such as roads, telecommunications, ports, electricity, and other services.

    A functioning internal economy provides the government with an income to buy goods and services, and also provides the private sector with capital to buy goods and services that it needs. A functioning internal economy also leads to the creation of goods and services that the country can competitively sell to the world market.

    Even countries that have a limited internal economy but are rich in natural resources, (such as Saudi Arabia in its early stage of development) are able to trade, assuming an initial investment in basic infrastructure. Therefore, the basic pre-conditions of trade are peace, a stable government, a functioning economy, and a supporting infrastructure.

    Trade requires the presence of a stable government as a precondition for its ability to buy and sell goods in the international market. In order to trade effectively, a country has to have a functioning internal economy, which should include basic infrastructure such as roads, telecommunications, ports, electricity, and other services.

    A functioning internal economy provides the government with an income to buy goods and services, and also provides the private sector with capital to buy goods and services that it needs. A functioning internal economy also leads to the creation of goods and services that the country can competitively sell to the world market.

    Even countries that have a limited internal economy but are rich in natural resources, (such as Saudi Arabia in its early stage of development) are able to trade, assuming an initial investment in basic infrastructure. Therefore, the basic pre-conditions of trade are peace, a stable government, a functioning economy, and a supporting infrastructure.

  • Trade Structure
  • It is essential to have the knowledge of world trade patterns to understand the movement of cargo across the globe. It also helps sellers, buyers, and carriers plan their business operations accordingly.

    Countries form regional groups or Trade Blocs and together facilitate trade amongst the members of the bloc. 

    They create a unified interface with other nations and blocs. 

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • There are many regional blocs but the largest are the North American Trade Agreement (NAFTA) and the European Union (EU) made up of the 25 Western and Central European countries, called the European Common Market. Other trade blocs exist in Latin America, Southeast Asia, Southern Africa, the Caribbean, and Central America. The map above illustrates the major trade blocs of the world.

    The following link provides more information on the roles of regional trade blocs.

  • Lesson Summary
    • The imposition of tariffs or duties is necessary to check the unfair exchange of goods between countries. Protection or retaliatory action such as temporary duty is imposed to resolve such problems.
    • Prior to the imposition of income taxes, which is a relatively recent phenomenon, customs duties often provided the primary source of Government revenues. The second reason for the imposition of tariffs is to protect and nurture a homegrown industry.
    • Countervailing duties are another type of duty imposed to neutralize the effects of subsidized exports by a foreign government. 
    • The most basic precondition for trade is peace.
    • A functioning internal economy provides the government with an income to buy goods and services, and also provides the private sector with capital to buy goods and services that it needs. A functioning internal economy also leads to the creation of goods and services that the country can competitively sell to the world market.
    • The most significant factor affecting the amount of trade that occurs is economic growth. Exchange rates are another major driver of trade.
    • Multipurpose ships of all nations are generally free to engage in worldwide ocean trade without restrictions. Based on the breakbulk trade pattern, they carry cargo from developed countries to developing countries.
  • Learning Outcomes
  • Upon the successful completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Identify the differences between intermodal and multimodal transportation. 
    • Analyze the three fundamental shipping markets. 
    • Explain the different stakeholders in cargo movement. 
    • Discuss the different roles of cargo interests. 
    • Explain how third-party service providers support breakbulk shipping.
  • Transportation Options in Trade
  • In most cases, the shipper has to use multiple transport options to send the cargo to the consignee. To stream line this operation, multi modal shipping has been introduced and it has grown very effectively in the last two decades, using the Information Technology. With the growth of Internet of Things (IoT) in Shipping, tracking the cargo and monitoring the condition of the cargo, especially in reefer containers have become possible. The shipper and the consignee have to understand some common terminologies, used in Multi modal shipping to avoid any risks. Other than these common terminologies, the questions on;
    • Who will pay the freight and up to what limit and
    • Who will pay for the insurance of the cargo and up to what limit
    • How is the payment made for the cargo
  • have to be answered correctly and documented, since the shipper and the consignee in most cases are from different countries, the cost of litigation on a later date will be huge. We will discuss some of these, in the subsequent topics.

  • Introduction to Shipping Markets
  • There are three fundamental shipping markets. They are:
    • Dry bulk market
    • Liquid bulk market
    • Liner market
  • A maritime logistician must understand these market dynamics and pay particular attention to the market/s in which they operate or specialize. The contents of this section will keep you abreast of contemporary developments on an annual basis which you must update with emerging data for the year as they become available.

  • Cargo Interests 
  • When the term "cargo interests" is used, it refers to the owners of the cargo. The owners of the cargo are the ultimate customers of the service providers involved in the transit, whether they are an ocean carrier, logistics company or marine terminal. It is the transaction created by the sale of a good from the buyer to the seller that gives rise to all the services required to move the goods from origin to destination.

    As the customer, the buyer or seller, depending on who assumes the role of the shipper, has decision making responsibility as to which carrier, forwarder or other service providers are selected and which port the goods are routed through. As a result, customers are very demanding. They demand quality service at a competitive price. 

    Although they are the customer, the buyer and seller have obligations they must fulfill. See the graphic below to understand the roles of the buyer, the seller and the shipper. As we know, the shipper may be either the buyer or seller, depending on which party takes responsibility for transportation under the terms of sale.

The owners of the cargo are the ultimate customers of the service providers involved in the transit, whether they are an ocean carrier, logistics company or marine terminal. It is the transaction created by the sale of a good from the buyer to the seller that gives rise to all the services required to move the goods from origin to destination.

    As the customer, the buyer or seller, depending on who assumes the role of the shipper, has decision making responsibility as to which carrier, forwarder or other service providers are selected and which port the goods are routed through. As a result, customers are very demanding. They demand quality service at a competitive price. 

    Although they are the customer, the buyer and seller have obligations they must fulfill. See the graphic below to understand the roles of the buyer, the seller and the shipper. As we know, the shipper may be either the buyer or seller, depending on which party takes responsibility for transportation under the terms of sale.

  • Cargo Movements
  • The process of begins with the sale of the product to be shipped. Every business of shipment is facilitating a transaction in which a buyer has acquired a commodity, product, piece of machinery or other goods from a seller. This involves negotiation of sale and shipment terms between the seller and the buyer. A key consideration is the question regarding the party responsible for the cost and arrangement of transportation.

    The INCOTERMS (discussed later) determine the responsibilities of each party relative to the transportation. Often both the buyer and the seller will have responsibility for one or more segments of the transportation process. One of the parties is responsible for arranging and paying for ocean transportation and is therefore known as the shipper. The shipper makes a basic determination on whether to utilize a liner service or charter a vessel in order to accomplish the ocean transit.
    • New Tab
      Enter your text here..
      Enter your text here..
    • Liner Service
      A liner service is a shipping service in which vessels are operated by a shipping company and call at a predetermined list of major ports known as a "rotation." The ships "rotate" among the ports in the schedule. A bulk of Container shipping services operate in this fashion. Breakbulk liner services are most useful when the shipper has a relatively small amount of cargo that is moving between major ports.
      Enter your text here..
    • Chartering
      In cases where liner operators cannot call at the port a shipper needs its cargo to go to, the shipper must charter a ship. Chartering involves leasing a vessel for a single voyage or for multiple voyages. A shipper may charter an entire vessel or, if he doesn't have enough cargo to fill an entire ship, he may elect to engage in a partial vessel charter.

      Both chartering and utilizing a liner service involve extensive coordination between the shipper and the provider of the ship. Breakbulk cargo by definition is unique. Few pieces of breakbulk cargo are the same, and no two projects are identical. Therefore, the dialogue between the shipper and the provider of the ship most delve into the specific details of the cargo and its specific requirements.
      Enter your text here..

  • Lesson Summary
    • Multimodal is using various modes of transport but with one transport bill of lading.
    • Intermodal shipping is when your shipments are handled by several different shipping companies. Intermodal is the movement of cargo from origin to destination by several modes of transport where each of these modes has a different transport carrier responsible and having its own independent contract. 
    • The difference between multimodal and intermodal lies in the contract/ bill of lading and transport carrier responsibility/liability of the movement.
    • Synchromodal shipping is the effective integration of the main elements in shipping namely distance, time, cost and emissions, of the various modes of transport.
    • There are three fundamental shipping markets. They are:
      - Dry bulk market
      - Liquid bulk market
      - Liner market
    • When the term "cargo interests" is used, it refers to the owners of the cargo. 
    • Third-party service providers support the breakbulk shipping process. Third-party refers to a service provider in addition to the primary shipper and carrier (the first party and second party) that fulfils various aspects of the logistics process. 
  • Learning Outcomes
  • Upon the successful completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Outline the different risks involved in the export of goods. 
    • Identify the roles and functions of the International Commercial Terms (INCOTERMS).
    • Explain the four categories of INCOTERMS. 
    • Analyze the main methods of payment. 
    • Discuss the three different payment methods under the settlement methods of LC.
  • Export Risks 
  • In an international sales contract, the Seller, Buyer, carrier and underwriter are all subject to risks in their relationships with each other. These can be minimised by having a sales contract and using the international commercial terms (Incoterms).

    Incoterms are most important in defining the risk distribution between parties involved in the transportation of goods from origin to destination in international trade. They also help eliminate common barriers in a sales contract. The risks in relationships in the export of goods are as follows:
    • New Tab
      Enter your text here..
      Enter your text here..
    • Seller & Buyer
      The Seller will find it difficult to enforce a right of property several miles away and therefore may find it difficult to get payment from the Buyer even though the goods are according to specifications of the negotiated sales contract between an international Buyer and Seller.

      The Buyer on the other hand is not sure that the goods meet the specifications as per the negotiated sales contract, when he makes payment before delivery.
      Enter your text here..
    • Seller/Buyer & the Carrier
      Even though the Seller has fulfilled his part of the bargain he could incur loss in the sale if there are delays in transportation. The Buyer on the other hand could lose if the goods are damaged during transit. The Carrier would be liable for damages if damage to goods was caused by the vessel not being seaworthy at the beginning of the voyage.
      Enter your text here..
    • Seller/Buyer & Underwriter
      The Underwriter will have to pay claims for damage and delay, provided there was no negligence on the part of the Carrier. Normally the risk of damage during transportation of goods is transferred to the Buyer once the goods are loaded on the vessel, even though the Seller may have arranged the insurance for the transport of the goods depends on the Incoterm.
      Enter your text here..
    • Seller/Buyer and Financier
      The Financier of the sale will lose if the Buyer does not make payment to the Seller. This is because the Seller may not be able to repay the loan that may have been taken to finance the manufacture of the good(s).
      Enter your text here..

  • Modes of Payment
  • The method of payment in a sales contract is as negotiated between the Buyer and Seller. There are 4 main methods of payment. These are:
    • The Cash with Order
    • The Open Account
    • The Bill of Exchange
    • The Documentary Letter of Credit
    • New Tab
    • Cash with Order
    • Open Account
    • Bill of Exchange
    • Enter your text here..
      Enter your text here..
    • In this method of payment the Buyer pays the Seller as soon as the order is given or the sales contract is agreed to. It is not a safe method of payment for a Buyer in international trade as the Seller could take the money and not deliver the goods. The Seller could also deliver goods that are substandard.

      This mode, is however, used when there is a good level of trust between the Seller and the Buyer.
      In this method of payment the Buyer pays the Seller as soon as the order is given or the sales contract is agreed to. It is not a safe method of payment for a Buyer in international trade as the Seller could take the money and not deliver the goods. The Seller could also deliver goods that are substandard.

      This mode, is however, used when there is a good level of trust between the Seller and the Buyer.
    • In this method of payment the Seller dispatches goods after the sales contract is confirmed, and awaits payment into his bank account at a later date. In this method of payment the Seller is at a disadvantage as the Buyer could take delivery of the goods and not make payment.

      This mode, is however, used when there is a good level of trust between the Seller and the Buyer.
      In this method of payment the Seller dispatches goods after the sales contract is confirmed, and awaits payment into his bank account at a later date. In this method of payment the Seller is at a disadvantage as the Buyer could take delivery of the goods and not make payment.

      This mode, is however, used when there is a good level of trust between the Seller and the Buyer.
    • The bill of exchange is a document similar to a cheque where the ‘drawer’ (the person who writes the bill of exchange) asks the ‘drawee’ (the party directed to pay) to pay the ‘payee’ a said amount on a certain date.

      The bill of exchange can be negotiable, which would mean that the ‘payee’ can take payment from the ‘drawee’ at a date earlier than the date of this bill and if this is done payment is normally discounted (would mean that the payee will not get the full value of the bill).

      This mode, is however, used when there is a good level of trust between the Seller and the Buyer.
    • The bill of exchange is a document similar to a cheque where the ‘drawer’ (the person who writes the bill of exchange) asks the ‘drawee’ (the party directed to pay) to pay the ‘payee’ a said amount on a certain date.

      The bill of exchange can be negotiable, which would mean that the ‘payee’ can take payment from the ‘drawee’ at a date earlier than the date of this bill and if this is done payment is normally discounted (would mean that the payee will not get the full value of the bill).

      A bill of exchange is given to the Seller (the payee) by the Buyer (the drawer) as payment. The ‘drawee’ could be a bank.

    • Cash with Order
      In this method of payment the Buyer pays the Seller as soon as the order is given or the sales contract is agreed to. It is not a safe method of payment for a Buyer in international trade as the Seller could take the money and not deliver the goods. The Seller could also deliver goods that are substandard.

      This mode, is however, used when there is a good level of trust between the Seller and the Buyer.

  • Lesson Summary
    • In an international sales contract, the Seller, Buyer, carrier and underwriter are all subject to risks in their relationships with each other.
    • Risks can be minimised by having a sales contract and using the international commercial terms (INCOTERMS).
    • There are four categories of INCOTERMS and these are: 
      - The ‘E’ Terms – Departure.
      - The ‘F’ terms – the main carriage unpaid.
      - The ‘C’ terms – the main carriage paid.
      - The ‘D’ terms – arrival.
    • INCOTERMS are a set of three-letter codes which represent the different ways in which international shipments are organized. INCOTERMS allow sellers and buyers from different cultures and legal systems to decide at which point the ownership and payment for freight, insurance, and customs costs transfer from one to the other.
    • There are 4 main methods of payment:
      - The Cash with Order
      - The Open Account
      - The Bill of Exchange
      - The Documentary Letter of Credit
  • Learning Outcomes
  • Upon the successful completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Discuss the concept of the supply chain. 
    • Analyze some supply chain management principles. 
    • Outline the ways in which maritime logistic and maritime transport are integrated. 
    • Identify the four different perspectives of Supply Chain Management and Logistics.
    • Outline some important professional organizations for a maritime logistician. 
  • Definition of Supply Chain 
  • The most commonly used definition of Supply chain is given by Council of Supply Chain Management Professionals (CSCMP). It defines supply chain as "the planning and management of all activities involved in sourcing and procurement, conversion and all logistics management activities. Importantly it also includes coordination and collaboration with channel partners, which can be suppliers, intermediaries, third-party service providers, and customers. In essence, supply chain management integrates supply and demand management within and across companies".

    The Supply Chain Management principles, when applied to the maritime industry as done in this course, provides knowledge of maritime operations and supply chain management to meet the needs of regional, national, and international shipping; intermodal transportation; and distribution industries.

    The modern dynamics in the supply chain business is well expressed by Art Mesher, CEO of Descartes Systems, stated: “As supply chain professionals, we are now chartered with managing a global set of resources in motion. Our scope is expanding once again. People, resources, truck drivers, field services workers, merchandisers, warehouse workers. All resources in motion.”

  • Professional Organizations
  • As a Maritime Logistician, you must know about the various professional organizations in your field. These entities provide training and certification courses in the field that is very helpful besides being an excellent avenue for networking and establishing professional contacts.

    • Association for Operations Management (APICS)
      APICS is a worldwide network of accomplished industry professionals that builds operations management excellence in individuals and enterprises through superior education and training, internationally recognized certifications and comprehensive resources.

      The various certification courses offered by APICS are Production and Inventory Management (CPIM), Certified Supply Chain Professional (CSCP), and Certified in Integrated Resource Management (CIRM). For more information log on to http://www.apics.org/apics
      APICS is a worldwide network of accomplished industry professionals that builds operations management excellence in individuals and enterprises through superior education and training, internationally recognized certifications and comprehensive resources.

      The various certification courses offered by APICS are Production and Inventory Management (CPIM), Certified Supply Chain Professional (CSCP), and Certified in Integrated Resource Management (CIRM). For more information log on to http://www.apics.org/apics
    • American Society of Transportation and Logistics, INC. (AST&L)
      AST&L is the professional organization of shippers, carriers, educators, consultants and third-party logistics individuals. Certification program like CTL (Certified in Transportation and Logistics), DLP (Distinguished Logistics Professional) and PLS (Professional Designation in Supply Chain Management) are provided for education and certification in the fields of transportation, logistics, and supply chain management.

      AST&L is affiliated with the National Industrial Transportation League (NITL) in the U.S. and provides educational services for its vast membership. For more information please visit AST&L.

      Maine Maritime Academy (MMA) is an ASTL - approved university and those who complete a degree in logistics/supply chain management from MMA will receive the CTL certification without appearing for the ASTL exams.

      Founded as the National Council of Physical Distribution Management (NCPDM) in January 1963, CSCMP is the preeminent worldwide professional association of Supply Chain Management professionals. It helps supply chain managers network with each other, learn from and collaborate with each other, and become more effective professionals. For more information visit CSCMP.

    • Association for Operations Management (APICS)
      APICS is a worldwide network of accomplished industry professionals that builds operations management excellence in individuals and enterprises through superior education and training, internationally recognized certifications and comprehensive resources.

      The various certification courses offered by APICS are Production and Inventory Management (CPIM), Certified Supply Chain Professional (CSCP), and Certified in Integrated Resource Management (CIRM). For more information log on to http://www.apics.org/apics

    • American Society of Transportation and Logistics, INC. (AST&L)
      AST&L is the professional organization of shippers, carriers, educators, consultants and third-party logistics individuals. Certification program like CTL (Certified in Transportation and Logistics), DLP (Distinguished Logistics Professional) and PLS (Professional Designation in Supply Chain Management) are provided for education and certification in the fields of transportation, logistics, and supply chain management.

      AST&L is affiliated with the National Industrial Transportation League (NITL) in the U.S. and provides educational services for its vast membership. For more information please visit AST&L.

      Maine Maritime Academy (MMA) is an ASTL - approved university and those who complete a degree in logistics/supply chain management from MMA will receive the CTL certification without appearing for the ASTL exams.

  • Lesson Summary
    • The Council of Supply Chain Management Professionals (CSCMP) defines a supply chain as "the planning and management of all activities involved in sourcing and procurement, conversion and all logistics management activities.
    • The Supply Chain Management principles, when applied to the maritime industry as done in this course, provides knowledge of maritime operations and supply chain management to meet the needs of regional, national, and international shipping; intermodal transportation; and distribution industries.
    • The modern dynamics in the supply chain business is well expressed by Art Mesher, CEO of Descartes Systems, stated: “As supply chain professionals, we are now chartered with managing a global set of resources in motion. Our scope is expanding once again. People, resources, truck drivers, field services workers, merchandisers, warehouse workers. All resources in motion.”
    • Maritime transport is a major facilitator of international commerce and deals with the transportation of goods and/or passengers from one seaport to the other. The vital role maritime transport plays in facilitating global supply chains is understood by all.
    • The following are professional organizations a maritime logistician can belong to: 
      - Association for Operations Management (APICS)
      - American Society of Transportation and Logistics, INC. (AST&L)
      - Council of Supply Chain Management Professionals (CSCMP)
  • Learning Outcomes 
  • Upon the successful completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Explain the difference between intermodal and multimodal transport.
    • Outline the major factors which influence supply chain operations.
    • Discuss the importance of planning in breakbulk shipping transit.
    • Identify the key elements in the economic regulation of liner shipping.
    • Outline the advantages and disadvantages of different modes of transport.
  • History of Intermodalism
  • Intermodalism originated in maritime transportation, with the development of the container in the late 1960s and has since spread to integrate other modes. It is not surprising that the maritime sector should have been the first mode to pursue containerization. It was the mode most constrained by the time taken to load and unload the vessels. A conventional breakbulk cargo ship could spend as much time in a port as it did at sea. Containerization permits the mechanized handling of cargoes of diverse types and dimensions that are placed into boxes of standard sizes. In this way goods that might have taken days to be loaded or unloaded from a ship can now be handled in a matter of minutes.

    Since the 1960s major efforts have been made to integrate separate transport systems through intermodalism, which took place in several stages. What initially began as improving the productivity of shipping, evolved into an integrated supply chain management system across modes. This involves the use of at least two different modes in a trip from origin to destination through an intermodal transport chain. Intermodality enhances the economic performance of a transport chain by using modes in the most productive manner. 

    Thus, the line-haul economies of rail may be exploited for long distances, with the efficiencies of trucks providing flexible local pickup and delivery. The key is that the entire trip is seen as a whole, rather than as a series of legs, each marked by an individual operation with separate sets of documentation and rates. Geography of Transport Systems: (Authors: Dr Jean-Paul Rodrigue, Dr Brian Slack and Dr Claude Comtois).

    According to RetailNext Inc,, in 2017, the number of shoppers in US stores on Thanksgiving and Black Friday fell 4 percent from last year; The Adobe Analytics reports online sales over $5.03 billion, a 16.9 percent increase over the prior year. This reflects a fundamental change in consumer buying, thus requiring supply chains to adapt by more closely managing the flow of goods for both online and brick-and-mortar fulfillment.

  • Planning the Transit
  • There is nothing more important to a successful end to end breakbulk shipping transit than planning. Planning involves understanding and anticipating all possible delays, challenges, and issues that may arise during the transit from ultimate origin to ultimate destination. Without properly understanding the many obstacles that may arise during the breakbulk shipping process it is possible, if not likely, that delays, cost overruns or damage to the goods will be the result. 

    The consequences are severe. They include loss of reputation, delaying and disrupting the project, incurring additional shipping and other costs, and damage to the cargo.

    Probably the most important aspect of planning is coordination. The breakbulk shipping process involves the participation of many different parties, all of whom must work with each other smoothly and effectively during the entire length of the transit. Effective coordination involves continuously sharing information with participating parties such as the shipper, consignee, marine terminal, stevedores, forwarders, packers, the ocean carrier, and surveyors. Other factors to be taken into account include ensuring compliance with regulations, accurate completion of documentation, and avoidance of physical logistical limitations.

    Planning should cover all aspects of the transit, from ensuring that clearances are sufficient along the intended route, to chartering of the ship, to the successful delivery of the goods to the final destination.

  • There is nothing more important to a successful end to end breakbulk shipping transit than planning. Planning involves understanding and anticipating all possible delays, challenges, and issues that may arise during the transit from ultimate origin to ultimate destination. Without properly understanding the many obstacles that may arise during the breakbulk shipping process it is possible, if not likely, that delays, cost overruns or damage to the goods will be the result. 

    The consequences are severe. They include loss of reputation, delaying and disrupting the project, incurring additional shipping and other costs, and damage to the cargo.

    Probably the most important aspect of planning is coordination. The breakbulk shipping process involves the participation of many different parties, all of whom must work with each other smoothly and effectively during the entire length of the transit. Effective coordination involves continuously sharing information with participating parties such as the shipper, consignee, marine terminal, stevedores, forwarders, packers, the ocean carrier, and surveyors. Other factors to be taken into account include ensuring compliance with regulations, accurate completion of documentation, and avoidance of physical logistical limitations.

    Planning should cover all aspects of the transit, from ensuring that clearances are sufficient along the intended route, to chartering of the ship, to the successful delivery of the goods to the final destination.

  • Intermodal and Multimodal
  • These two terms are often used interchangeably, but there is a difference.
    • Intermodal – is the movement of cargo from origin to destination by several modes of transport where each of these modes has a different transport provider or entity responsible, each with its own independent contract which means Multiple carriers during a single journey
    • Multimodal – is the movement of cargo from origin to destination by several modes of transport where each of these modes has a different transport provider or entity responsible, but under a single contract. Single carrier during a single journey 
  • The key functions of both terminologies are the same, but the differentiation lies in the contract and responsibility of the movement.

  • Importance of Transshipment
  • For most advanced economies with large port infrastructure, the transshipment takes a major lead in building the economic activities of the nation, measured by its GDP. It is no coincidence that the EU, Hong Kong, Singapore and the United States depends on re-export of goods through their hub ports. Transshipment ports today, are advanced with automation and huge acceleration of container movements across the network of shipping services that include large hub ports and smaller ports connectivity via feeder services.

    In order to satisfy the demands of carriers, transshipment ports need to satisfy a number of attributes: 
    • Availability of an array of high-frequency feeder services, connecting the hub with its network of feeder ports
    • A convenient geographical location with access to major trade routes and other transshipment centres
    • Efficient, highly productive and competitively priced port and terminal services
    • Availability of modern high-tech infrastructure (e.g., berths, gantry cranes, container storage space) as well as equipment that allows for a quick turnaround time of large vessels.

  • Lesson Summary
    • Intermodalism originated in maritime transportation, with the development of the container in the late 1960s and has since spread to integrate other modes.
    • There are five major factors which influence supply chain operations:
      - Cost
      - Risk
      - Speed
      - Innovation
      - Agility
    • Chief Operating Officers need to minimize operational costs, automate and improve productivity. To do this, they need to remove manual processes and improve visibility. 
    • When two or more modes of transportation are used in an integrated fashion to facilitate a cargo movement, it is referred to as intermodalism. The integration takes place through the use of a single bill of lading and with through liability for the multiple movements.
    • There is nothing more important to a successful end to end breakbulk shipping transit than planning. Planning involves understanding and anticipating all possible delays, challenges, and issues that may arise during the transit from ultimate origin to ultimate destination.
    • A multimodal operation is more convenient for the shipper, and thus tend to be more expensive; whereas the contracts with a number of entities could give competitive pricing, and choice of mode of shipment e.g., truck or railcars to choose from, but operationally tend to be more hazardous due to possible “delay spots” and communication problems in the total value chain.
